AboutMe.Things:
My first experience in any sort of programming was in a small game known as roblox. I made small games and was absolutely captivated when I was able to make a brick change colour. From here, I was hooked, tinkering my way into the development team of a medium sized minecraft server known as HarvestMC.
I continued growing and tinkering my way into a formal education at The University of Newcastle, before landing an internship and a graduate program at Boeing Defence Australia.
My strength comes in my breadth of knowledge. Being exposed and experimenting with new ideas and new tools since a young age, I've become accustomed to the way I learn and am able to pick up new skillsets as needed.
While not behind the computer, I enjoy spending time making music, behind the camera, or in the gym.

Items.Description:
Upon joining this software team, I was launched straight into the deep end in a full development cycle. Picking up the differences between a Git Trunk cycle compared to a Git Flow was a sudden change. But once I was in the swing of things, it felt natural and created a positive development expereince.
This team challenged me to improve my software engineering skills drastically, with the need to get code through reviews with the standards set by the senior engineers, I quickly weeded out common mistakes and misconceptions I was making while I was writing software.
Once the development cycle finished, I was involved in writing the engineering documentation of the product. Ensuring we had valid tests to meet the requirements set by the customer, and detailed documentation of the architecture and inner workings of the product.

Following on from the Internship, I built upon my existing skillset, gaining more experience with Containerisaiton and continuing into using podman. The first major assignment I took on in this role was the transition of the project from Clearcase to Git development. This involved working with multiple stake holders and really taught the need for clear and open communication.
With this new development process, camee the need for a new environment. Solid computer science foundations meant picking up ansible was quick and natural and allowed an environment that can be recreated relaibly. The everyday responsibilities of this role also involved the maintenance of the CI/CD pipeline, Jenkins Administration and Atlassian Administraiton.

The internship was my introduction to the industry. It began with me developing a business case for the vulnerability assessment tool openscap and artifact management tool artifactory, and developed into being the point of contact for the containerization of the Atlassian Suite tools. This kind of role broke me into the environment of working on a live system rather quickly, emphasising the need for a solid pipeline and realistic testing environmnet.

I thoroughly enjoy my time at the University of Newcastle. Gaining a broad skillset and learning softskills such as working in a team were built directly into the degree. I built a solid skillset in the foundations of Software Engineering, Cyber Security and Computer Science.

Items.Title: Maze Runner
Items.Subtitle: Maze Algorithm Comparison
Items.Description: A short curiousity project of mine. Designed to compare the efficiencies of different pathfinding algorithms when solving a maze.

Items.Title: Chronos
Items.Subtitle: University Final Project
Items.Description: This was my final year university project, completed in a small group. Designed to assist students in organizing a complex timetable with a variety of requirements. It allowed users to drag and drop their time table around, with tiles that change colour to determine if your timetable is valid, or if a course is being done in the correct order. There is also an auto-sort feature to enable students to set restrictions for the timetable.
